Leave the computer on so the fan will be running and the box warms up again, to try to dry it out. Go away for a few minutes and wait. Heart racing. Come back. Say a prayer. One eye opened, tentatively strike a key. Oh hallelujah. It works!

@AukeHoekstra @MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Is anyone doing any actual work to turn that philosophy into practice?
@AukeHoekstra @MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Yes, I am aware of that. The difference is, I believe that policy prescriptions should be practical and actionable.

@AukeHoekstra @MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Now I think we should do whatever we must to measure things and make sustainable decisions, but in the end, we should reject the tyranny of cost-benefit analysis as the only valid basis for decision-making, and feel free to apply our values and just preserve what we care about.

@AukeHoekstra @MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep True, and I think our methodology, using dollars as that common denominator, to quantify the unquantified and internalize the externalized, is better than the status quo. But in the end I decided that even doing that leaves intact an economics lens that is fundamentally blind.

@AukeHoekstra @MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep I'm not sure if I agree with that or not. But I absolutely do believe that what humans value, or what contributes to human welfare in some obvious way, is not all that is valuable. Metrics like GDP lose sight of things like stewardship.

@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Except that same wetlands is also habitat for a number of rare birds and other species that have no market value and no alternative or analog that can be assigned a value.
@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Don't change the subject Michael. We're talking about GDP and its alternatives here.
@AukeHoekstra @MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Clearly, Auke, if you can't sell it to someone else at a dollar value, it doesn't exist.

@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep There is a huge distance between quantifying *zero* natural capital and quantifying *all* effects. You can't say that it's not even worth trying to value that which GDP does not recognize because it can't *all* be done perfectly or without applying value judgments.

@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Natural capital *cannot* be quantified by commodity values or cash flows until it is consumed, at which point it is no longer natural capital. What's the value of an acre of intact, un-harvested wetlands' capacity to absorb storm surges and prevent flooding?

@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep This is not just armchair rhetoric for me. I turned theory into practice with this project under a Rockefeller Foundation grant: https://t.co/yV753UINMb 
It's a challenging kind of analysis but it's quite straightforward in theory.

@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep I would argue the opposite: It may be easier to just quantify assets, but it is surely more *rigorous* to count all effects, including the less-tangible ones. But that aside, the hardest (and most relevant) bit is quantifying natural capital, which *is* an asset.

@MLiebreich @ramez @MiriamvGool @AukeHoekstra @KateRaworth @theiirc @camjhep Not sure what your point is. What do you suppose is included in those big ‚Äúsix capitals‚Äù buckets you like? It‚Äôs all the same stuff once you go to measure it‚Ä¶

@eamonnlannoye @KevinSLeahy @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq Again, one of the biggest being that basically all EVs are currently owned by people who can charge at home. And the last ~40% of EVs will be charged in different places at 10-100x the speed by people who can't. Basically impossible to model.
@stephenjudkins @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq I don't even let V2G in my head right now.

@llisonwndrland @agelston @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq You can model travel patterns. What you cannot accurately model is the charging speeds (1.7-350 kW), the kWh consumed per session (10-100), when they charge (anytime), where the charging stations are (anywhere), the cars' efficiency (2.5-5+ mi/kWh). Esp. now, at 1% of the fleet.
@agelston @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq Where all of the same caveats apply! To be clear: It is *not possible* to accurately model demand at this point in time. Full stop. But that is an interesting approach.
@DrChrisClack @gilbeaq @robbieorvis @VibrantCE @CommEnergyInc Ah, fair enough. OK, *most* models don't allow for that kind of evolution. ;-)
@benserrurier üò•

@KevinSLeahy @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq Generally. EPRI's model has its own shortcomings. Again, when you're starting from a base of 2% market share and 1% vehicles on the road and charger speeds, locations, vehicle efficiencies, etc. are all moving targets...Caveat emptor on ALL projections. Could be off by 100%.
@KevinSLeahy @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq Again - Results from that model should not be taken at face value. The assumptions are critical. Much guesswork embedded in all these models.

@scotthomasson @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq Yes but TOU is only helpful with encouraging managed charging on Level 2 chargers. Managed charging isn't really a thing in the DCFC sector (which the MUD dwellers will use primarily). What we need there is (gasp) demand charge relief.
@A_Siegel @gilbeaq I have spent many hours exploring the medium- and heavy-duty loads and I wouldn't even attempt a SWAG at that.

@gilbeaq @robbieorvis Correct. The kW will change depending on your model. The kWh will be pretty stable. BUT the number of miles a car can go on a kWh can vary by 100% and that changes year by year too as vehicle tech improves, and that isn't in anybody's model.

@scotthomasson @DeepShort7 @gilbeaq You would think so...and yet....üôÑ I've been traipsing all over the country for three years now talking to regulator commissions and utilities about this and 'taint so.

@robbieorvis @gilbeaq Right. Which is true today, when the EVs (~1% of vehicles) are owned by people who live in single family homes. But ~35-40% of all people live in MUDs, with no place to charge overnight. You have to open up EVI-Pro and change the defaults to do more accurate modeling.
ü§£ü§£ü§£ https://t.co/DcRFoxSx6q

@gilbeaq @robbieorvis Caveat emptor: The NREL default modeling tends to assume far too much charging at home & workplace and far too little at high-speed public chargers. Lotta stuff buried in those assumptions.
@DeepShort7 @gilbeaq I think we've been over this before. No. That's a very complex function of an unknown number of vehicles charging at different speeds and places and times and penetration rates.

@gilbeaq The generally-accepted rule of thumb for the US is that if you electrified the entire LDV fleet overnight, it would increase total US electricity demand by about 25%. And EVs are ~2% of sales and ~1% of vehicles on the road now. Between those points is all guesswork.

@JeffLFox @ramez @Noahpinion @nebulousmenace @JesseJenkins @KenCaldeira "Flexible demand" is a broad, non-technical term referring to all sorts of devices and ways of reducing OR increasing demand, in order to take advantage of a tariff or spot pricing or grid conditions generally, and isn't RE-specific at all.

@JeffLFox @ramez @Noahpinion @nebulousmenace @JesseJenkins @KenCaldeira I would say...neither. 
"Demand response" is a technical term usually referring to when a utility puts out a notice (e.g., on the Open ADR system) asking users to reduce load, and then compensates users for doing it through mechanisms described in their tariffs.

@Rory_Johnston @GNSensay I do not. I smoke them with just the dry rub for about 2 hours, then I start painting them with my homemade BBQ sauce every 15 mins or so for another ~1.5 hours. The sauce creates a crust that helps seal in the moisture.
@Rory_Johnston Sure thing! I've been working on my ribs technique for 20 years now. It's a journey. And soooo worth it. https://t.co/GGdrJNVJpg

@Rory_Johnston Packing in charcoal is never a problem if you know how to control the bottom vents. It's all about the air flow, not the amount of fuel. Lotta amateurs out there who don't know what the bottom vents are for!

@Rory_Johnston To avoid having to do that step, I load the charcoal carefully and really pack it in tightly. Here's how it looks right before the meat goes on. (I whitened the briquets & poured over the mesquite chunks below.) https://t.co/An4I0ZJWEg

@Rory_Johnston You want to maintain a nice steady 220 or so. Also, I don't think you've got enough coals in there to make it 6 hours. So at some point you're going to want to remove the meat, keep it covered & warm, reload the coals, let them whiten, then take it from the top.
@Rory_Johnston The top vents should be wide open except when you're shutting down the heat. You want the smoke to flow out. And position the top vents over the meat.

@Rory_Johnston You gotta drive those vents like a Cadillac. Shut them all the way down when you first put on the meat, to let the coals cool off a bit. Then open about 1/4" to get the smoke flowing again. Then open a bit more if the temp drops. You just gotta watch it and keep adjusting.

@Rory_Johnston Note that I have stacked the ribs and kept them as far away from the charcoal as possible. The charcoal was whitened and hot before I put on the meat, and I shut down both top & bottom vents until the coals had cooled a bit. https://t.co/8VZV5FvsPL

@Rory_Johnston Nice. Here's my setup one year ago: https://t.co/Yw5QYKuvwI

I don't use a tray beneath, or spray water, or anything like that. It's all about controlling the BOTTOM vents. Keep the inside temp around 220¬∞ and keep the smoke going.

@SimonMahan If you can separately meter the EV, then you can offer it a special TOU rate which steers charging into the off-peak hours. That is a form of managed charging and doesn't require 2-way comms or any special kind of EVSE.
@LangReynolds @SolarInMASS An AMI submeter doesn't charge a car, so I'm not sure I understand that comparison.

@SimonMahan For the 92% of the US population who do not live in Texas, separately metering EVs is key to shaping their load and steering it into the valleys of the load profile. Implementing managed charging is much more difficult without it.
@SolarInMASS Yes, that's the point.

@kelly_c_roache @DavidPomerantz Count me as very confused as to how you found any "gendered" aspect to my comments. I was not critiquing the article at all. I didn't read it. I've just seen this spurious use of "fracked" a lot lately and I'm trying to correct that. It's a technical, but legitimate, point.
@DrewSmithee @DavidPomerantz @EnergyandPolicy @kelly_c_roache Be that as it may... how the gas is produced is irrelevant when you‚Äôre talking about consumption. That‚Äôs the key point.

@DavidPomerantz @EnergyandPolicy @kelly_c_roache We still produce plenty of conventional gas, coalbed methane gas, biogas, landfill gas, etc. "Fracked" should not be used as a random qualifier. It's specific to shale and should remain that way.

@DavidPomerantz @EnergyandPolicy @kelly_c_roache That may or may not be a safe assumption in this specific case, but it's confusing and irrelevant when it comes to consumption. I'm seeing this spurious use of "fracked" a lot, I know it's confusing writers and readers, and I'm on a mission to stamp it out. It's just gas.

@DavidPomerantz @EnergyandPolicy @kelly_c_roache The ONLY time you should call it "fracked" gas is if you are *exclusively* talking about gas produced from fracking (which will be never, if you're talking about consumption, not production). @JustinHGillis @jgkoomey @cfarndt @JesseJenkins @ramez I am well aware that the talking point about balancing costs has been repeated many times, for years. That doesn't make it correct or even worthy of counter-argument, but it does mean that we need to work harder to educate people about how the system actually works.

@HakonNordhagen @TransitionShow @liamdenning Thanks Hakon. Yes I very deliberately constrained that conversation to oil, because there was more than enough to talk about with just oil, and the gas market dynamics are so very different now. But I will take your suggestion to heart and think about doing another show on gas.

@jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @cfarndt @JesseJenkins @ramez 95% of the people who present that argument have no idea how any of this works, and are simply repeating a talking point they learned from someone on the losing end of the #energytransition... usually a FF or nuke industry propagandist. So the argument usually ends there.

@jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @cfarndt @JesseJenkins @ramez It is, but again, my way of addressing that very argument is to simply explain that system balancing costs are borne at the system level, not the generator level. That approach has worked well for me.

@jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @cfarndt @JesseJenkins @ramez I think the question of when/where a given solar or wind plant, with or without storage, is competitive with a gas peaking plant is, and should be, entirely separate from any questions about system balancing.

@JustinHGillis @cfarndt @jgkoomey @JesseJenkins @ramez Put another way... What was the thinking about the cost of system balancing before renewables came along? Because it should be the same, more or less, today.

@JustinHGillis @cfarndt @jgkoomey @JesseJenkins @ramez However, if one MUST model the cost of system balancing, then I think Jacob's methodology is sound. But I'm none too sure about what the application of that information would be.

@JustinHGillis @cfarndt @jgkoomey @JesseJenkins @ramez Again, my view is that there is no such thing as a "cost of intermittency" and so I don't think it needs to be modeled, nor does that argument need to be answered, beyond saying "system balancing is done (and paid for) at the system level."

@cfarndt @jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @JesseJenkins @ramez That's a *continuous* challenge for sys ops. Not just for RE, but for DERs, demand flexibility, standalone utility scale storage systems, and whatever else comes down the pike next! The costs are mainly a result of what generators will sell their power for, not what sys ops plan.

@jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @JesseJenkins @cfarndt @ramez The fact is there are no generators of any kind that are 100% reliable. They all go offline sometimes, for various reasons. It's the job of the sys op to figure out how to stitch together all the resources at their disposal to produce a steady and reliable flow of power.

@JesseJenkins @jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @cfarndt @ramez I don't think anyone would advocate for that. Equally, no one should advocate for larding up the cost of any RE plant with "backup" for the hours in which it is not operating. It's just the wrong way to think about it.

@JesseJenkins @jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @cfarndt @ramez Yah... conversely, one could ask what the "cost of intermittency" is for *any* plant. Should we lard up the LCOE of a 2 GW nuclear plant (the largest kind of reliability risk for a system operator) with the cost of ANOTHER 2 GW plant to compensate when it goes down?

@jgkoomey @JustinHGillis @JesseJenkins @cfarndt @ramez I'm not even sure why that's useful, frankly. I mean, it is, for the purpose of seeing how RE integration might evolve & affect the markets, but I still see that as very different from any notion of system balancing.

@JustinHGillis @JesseJenkins @cfarndt @ramez @jgkoomey I don't think that's the right approach, Justin. System balancing is done at the system level, not the generator level. There's no "cost of intermittency" unless you (incorrectly) think that all generators should act exactly like conventional thermal generators.

@FordneyEnergy @evcricket The relationship between retail rates and the cost of producing & distributing power is again highly complex, esp. in Cali. As is the history of various rate designs that have been tried, including flat. You might want to talk to @RegAssistProj about that.

@FordneyEnergy @evcricket Sure sure... the tricky part is understanding exactly why rates are what they are, and then whether those rates are justified given the social benefits realized. It's essential to understand the totality of the picture, and that picture is really, really complex.

@evcricket @FordneyEnergy Lots of other CBAs have shown similarly in the US. Just counting one set of subsidies while not counting the other set (social cost of carbon) and also not counting the benefits is definitely not the right way to measure ratepayer impact.

@siddharth3 @gnievchenko @IEA @EIAgov @MLiebreich Hang on. I didn't say, or mean to imply, that there are no scenarios that don't include efficiency. In this case, I would have been referring (of course) to the Reference Scenario. Or any other (e.g., oil demand) scenario derived from it.

I hope that eventually we're going to discover the value of turning down EV chargers too, just as some entities (like Nest) do today with other DERs like water/space heaters. The moral of the story? When you're thinking about #EnergyTransition, don't forget the power of down!

Or consider Ep. 87 with @ArneOlsonE3 on deliberately running solar plants below full capacity in order to be able to operate them more flexibly. https://t.co/OOY8aFIJ5c
Genius. And not factored into most solar project models, AFAIK.

Another example: This little project in Scotland, where they have so much wind on the system now, they can turn a hydro plant turbine off, and reserve it for system services. https://t.co/rxSSWkyrve Betcha exactly zero energy analysts had that in their future power mix models.
And then we are surprised when utilities keep forecasting electricity demand growth picking up again, starting NEXT YEAR, after a decade of flat or declining demand. "What did we miss?" we ask.

For example: Efficiency. Most energy analysts know that it should be the first tool in any box of #energytransition  solutions. But when agencies like @IEA or @EIAgov project (er...FORECAST) future energy demand, they generally don't factor it in.

And that got me to thinking about all the unexpected ways that #EnergyTransition involves solutions that we don't think about...often ones that involve turning stuff OFF. We seem to have a strong preference for turning stuff on!

@JigarShahDC @Ben_Geman @davidgaffen As EVs & other efficiencies pose an ever-growing threat to oil demand, that will only reduce the upper price bound. And as more cheap supply gets depleted, that will only raise the price floor. And the Goldilocks band will narrow again.
